data.name: Intended Directory (instance/statements/)
data.description: Allowed directory for user file downloads

data.name: Application Trust Boundary
data.description: Protected areas: app/, config files, system files

data.name: Attacker
data.description: Authenticated malicious user exploiting download endpoint

data.name: Flask Web Application - Download Route
data.description:
Description: "/download endpoint (GET)"
Privilege Level: "High"
Vulnerable Code: os.path.join(instance_path, filename)

threats.title: Insecure File Download Implementation
threats.description:
The /download endpoint implements file downloads without proper 
path validation, directory restrictions, or access controls.

Vulnerabilities:
1. No path normalization
2. No whitelist validation
3. No absolute path verification
4. No file extension checking
5. No access control verification

Attack Surface:
- Any authenticated user can exploit
- No rate limiting on download endpoint
- Error messages may leak directory structure

Business Impact:
- Loss of intellectual property (source code)
- Credential compromise
- Compliance violations (data breach)
- Potential for complete system compromise
threats.mitigation:
1. Implement secure path handling (use safe_join)
2. Whitelist allowed files or patterns
3. Add access control checks
4. Log all download attempts
5. Implement rate limiting
6. Use indirect reference map (filename ‚Üí UUID mapping)

data.name: File System
data.description: Contains app files, config files, system files

data.name: Vulnerable Path Construction
data.description:
Data: "os.path.join(instance_path, '../app/schema.sql')"
  Description: "Path constructed without validation"
  
  Vulnerable Code:
  filepath = os.path.join(app.instance_path, filename)
  # Result: instance/../app/schema.sql ‚Üí app/schema.sql
  
  ‚ö†Ô∏è NO VALIDATION:
  - No path normalization
  - No whitelist check
  - No absolute path verification

data.name: File System Access (Unauthorized)
data.description:
Protocol: File I/O
  Data: "Read request for app/schema.sql"
  Description: "Application reads file outside intended directory"
  
  Accessed Files:
  - app/schema.sql (database structure)
  - app/auth.py (source code)
  - app/__init__.py (config with credentials)

threats.title: Unauthorized File System Access
threats.description:
Application accesses files outside the intended directory due to 
lack of path validation, allowing authenticated users to read 
arbitrary files within application's file system permissions.

Technical Details:
Vulnerable Code:
@app.route('/download')
def download():
    filename = request.args.get('file')
    filepath = os.path.join(app.instance_path, filename)  # VULNERABLE!
    return send_file(filepath, as_attachment=True)

Problem:
os.path.join() does NOT prevent path traversal:
- os.path.join('/instance', '../app/file.py') ‚Üí '/app/file.py'
- Absolute paths in second argument override first argument
- No validation of final resolved path

Exploitation:
1. Normal use: /download?file=statement.pdf ‚Üí instance/statements/statement.pdf ‚úÖ
2. Attack: /download?file=../app/schema.sql ‚Üí app/schema.sql üî¥

data.name: Sensitive File Content
data.description:
Data: "Database schema, source code, configuration"
  Description: "File system returns unauthorized file content"
  
  Exposed Information:
  - Database structure and relationships
  - Application source code
  - Database credentials
  - API keys and secrets
  - System configuration

data.name: HTTP Response (File Download)
data.description:
Protocol: HTTP
  Data: "Sensitive file content as download"
  Content-Type: "application/octet-stream"
  Description: "Attacker receives unauthorized file"

data.name: Direct Database Access (Escalation)
data.description:
Protocol: SQLite
  Data: "Direct connection using stolen credentials"
  Description: "Attacker bypasses application and accesses DB directly"
  Impact: "Full data exfiltration"

data.name: HTTP GET (Path Traversal)
data.description:
Protocol: HTTP
  Data: "file=../app/schema.sql"
  URL: "http://localhost:5000/download?file=../app/schema.sql"
  Description: "Attacker sends request with path traversal payload"
  
  Attack Payload Examples:
  - ../app/schema.sql
  - ../app/auth.py
  - ../app/__init__.py
  - ../../etc/passwd
  - ../../../windows/system32/config/sam

threats.title: Path Traversal via File Parameter
threats.description:
Attacker manipulates the 'file' query parameter with path traversal 
sequences (../) to escape the intended directory (instance/statements/) 
and access sensitive files including source code, configuration files, 
and system files.

Attack Vector:
GET /download?file=../app/schema.sql
GET /download?file=../app/__init__.py
GET /download?file=../../etc/passwd

Impact:
- Exposure of database schema
- Source code disclosure
- Credential theft (DB passwords, API keys)
- System file access
- Potential for privilege escalation

Affected Asset:
- Flask Download Route (/download endpoint)
- File System (app/, config/, system directories)
threats.mitigation:
1. Path Normalization:
   - Use os.path.realpath() to resolve paths
   - Check if resolved path starts with allowed directory
   
2. Whitelist Validation:
   - Maintain list of allowed filenames
   - Only serve files from whitelist
   
3. Absolute Path Checking:
   allowed_dir = os.path.realpath(app.instance_path)
   file_path = os.path.realpath(os.path.join(allowed_dir, filename))
   if not file_path.startswith(allowed_dir):
       abort(403)
   
4. Input Sanitization:
   - Remove or reject ../ sequences
   - Validate filename format
   
5. Principle of Least Privilege:
   - Run application with minimal file system permissions

text.text:
üìù Attacker extracts:
  - DB credentials from __init__.py
  - API keys from config files
  - User data structure from schema.sql

data.name:
üìù Attacker extracts:

  - API keys from config files
  - User data structure from schema.sql

text.text:
üéØ PATH TRAVERSAL ATTACK FLOW:

1. Attacker: GET /download?file=../app/schema.sql
2. Flask: filepath = join(instance_path, '../app/schema.sql')
3. Result: instance/../app/schema.sql ‚Üí app/schema.sql
4. Flask: send_file('app/schema.sql')  ‚Üê Escapes intended directory!
5. Attacker: Downloads sensitive file
6. Attacker: Extracts credentials
7. Attacker: Direct database access

text.text:
üìÅ FILE SYSTEM STRUCTURE:

‚úÖ INTENDED (Allowed):
   /instance/statements/*.pdf

üî¥ RESTRICTED (Should be blocked):
   /app/*.py (source code)
   /app/*.sql (schema)
   /config/*.ini (credentials)
   /../ (parent directories)
   /etc/* (system files)

‚ö†Ô∏è VULNERABLE PATH:
   /download?file=../app/schema.sql
   ‚Üí Escapes /instance/statements/
   ‚Üí Accesses /app/schema.sql

text.text:
‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL VULNERABILITY

Impact: HIGH
Exploitability: EASY (just modify URL parameter)
Detection: LOW (looks like normal file access)

Exposed Files:
- app/schema.sql ‚Üí Database structure
- app/__init__.py ‚Üí DB credentials
- app/auth.py ‚Üí Authentication logic
- ../etc/passwd ‚Üí System users (Linux)

Escalation Path:
File Access ‚Üí Credentials ‚Üí Direct DB Access ‚Üí Full Data Breach

diagrams.title: INSECURE DIRECT OBJECT REFERENCE (IDOR) Attack Threat Model

threats.title: Broken Access Control
threats.description:
Endpoint lacks authorization logic to verify account ownership 
before displaying sensitive financial data.
threats.mitigation:
1. Implement ownership verification
2. Log all account access attempts
3. Rate limit account queries
4. Add account access audit trail

data.name: Authorization Check
data.reasonOutOfScope: This component is MISSING in the vulnerable implementation

threats.title: New STRIDE threat
threats.description: Provide a description for this threat
threats.mitigation: Provide remediation for this threat or a reason if status is N/A

threats.title: Missing Authorization Component
threats.description:
No authorization layer exists to enforce account isolation. 
This is a fundamental design flaw allowing horizontal privilege escalation.
threats.mitigation:
Implement authorization middleware that checks:
- Is user authenticated?
- Does account belong to user?
- Does user have permission to view account?

threats.title: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR)
threats.description:
Attacker manipulates account_id in URL from /account/1 to /account/2 
to access other users' account details without authorization check.
threats.mitigation:
1. Add authorization check: verify account['user_id'] == session['user_id']
2. Use indirect reference (UUID instead of sequential ID)
3. Implement role-based access control

data.name: Query Victim Account
data.description: SELECT * FROM accounts WHERE id = 2 (NO AUTH CHECK)

threats.title: Missing Authorization Check
threats.description:
Database query executes without verifying account ownership, 
allowing any authenticated user to access any account data.
threats.mitigation: Add SQL query filter: WHERE id = ? AND user_id = ?

text.text:
üéØ IDOR ATTACK FLOW:
  
  1. Attacker logs in (account_id=1)
  2. Views own account: /account/1 ‚úÖ
  3. Changes URL to: /account/2 üî¥
  4. Flask queries database (NO AUTH CHECK)
  5. Database returns Alice's data
  6. Attacker views Alice's balance: $5,000
  7. Repeat for /account/3, /account/4...
